Javier is currently working for a taxi company in the Colonia Jose Angel Ulloa, which is where he lives. He has served as the dispatcher and partner in the company for two years. He has a small grocery store but during the winter months the rain causes many problems in the area where Javier lives and his house collapsed and with it his business was lost. He needs this loan because he currently lives in his cousin's house and he wants to start with soft drinks and fruit to obtain extra income since his children are in school. His wife works by making and selling tortillas and the two of them have fought hard to reconstruct their house and they expect that the Government of the Republic will also help them. Javier is a very responsible and honest person.

Translated from Spanish by Donna Yates, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy soft drinks and fruit for resale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mirelia Margarita

texts.es: La  Sra. Mirelia tiene su pequeño negocio de productos de consumo diario, como ser queso, mantequilla, jugos,huevos, manteca, refrescos, su negocio esta ubicado en la Colonia Jose Angel Ulloa, ya cuenta con clientes fijos, inicio hace dos años y de a poco ha ido surtiendo su negocio con la ayuda de sus esposo el cual trabaja como Agente de Seguridad, tiene dos hijos, ella va dos veces por semana al mercado para poder obtener precios mas bajos, necesita el el credito para comprar mas productos y con esto incrementar sus ingresos y poder ofrecerles una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos, su sueño es poder hacer mas grande su negocio y ofrecer mas variedad de productos. Ella es una persona joven con mucho dinamismo, amable y responsable.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mirelia has a small business in products for daily consumption such as cheese, butter, juices, eggs, shortening, and soft drinks. Her business is located in the Colonia Jose Angel Ulloa, and right now she counts on steady customers. She started the business two years ago and little by little her business has become secure with the help of her husband who works as a security guard. They have two children. She goes twice a week to the market to buy merchandise at a much lower price. She needs this loan to buy more products and with it will increase her profits and will be able to offer a better quality of life to her children. Her dream is to be able to make her business much bigger and offer a greater variety of products. She is a friendly and responsible young person with a lot of dive.

Translated from Spanish by Donna Yates, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food products for resale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gladiz Amanda

texts.es: La  Sra. Gladiz  tiene su negocio de venta de Mercaderia varias como ser, ropa para dama, caballeros y niños, sandalias , perfumes, cremas , desodorantes. Desde hace cuatro años, ella viaja dos veces al mes a vender al Departamento de la Paz, donde ya tiene clientes fijos, la señora cuenta tambien con la ayuda de su esposo el que trabaja como Guardia de Seguridad, ellos tiene  tres hijos los cuales dos de ellos estudian, su otra hija tiene problemas de salud ya que hace un tiempo le detectaron una enfermedad llamada leucemia, y ella tiene que llevarla dos veces al hospital para recibir atencion medica y esto le genera gastos semanales de L.500.00, con los ingresos que recibe por las ventas ella ayuda al sustento de su familia, necesita el dinero para poder comprar mercaderia al por mayor a precio mas bajo y con esto obtener mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Gladiz has a business in the sale of various merchandise such as clothing for ladies, gentlemen and children, sandals, perfume, lotions, and deodorant. For 4 months, she has traveled two times a month to sell in the Department of La Pas, where she has steady customers. Mrs. Gladiz does the accounting as well, with the help of her husband who works as a security guard. They have three children, two of which are studying, and their other daughter has health problems seeing that some time back the illness called leukemia was detected, and she had to be taken two times to the hospital to receive medical attention and this generated final expenses of L. 500.00. With the profits that she receives from her sales, Mrs. Gladiz helps in the subsistence of her family. She needs merchandise so she can buy better merchandise for a lower price and with this she can obtain better profits.

Translated from Spanish by Donna Yates, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing, sandals, lingerie and lotions

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Fe Y Esperanza - Faith And Hope Group

texts.es: El grupo Fe y Esperanza , son mujeres que se llevan bien, sociables, vecinas y familiares. Ellas viven en la Col. Nueva Esperanza y Venezuela que estan muy cerca. Wendy, una mujer joven, trabajadora desde hace 1 año, ella tiene una pequeña caseta la cual empieza atender desde temprano de 7: am hasta la 1:00 mediodia y luego vuelve abrir a las 3:00 pm y cierra a las 6:00 pm. Su negocio esta ubicado muy estrategicamente frente al campo de futbol y a la par del Centro de Salud de la comunidad, vende golosinas como ser Papas fritas, enchiladas, tacos y ademas lo mas preferido por sus clientes Granitas de café y mora. Los dias sabados es cuando mas vende porque llega bastante gente al campo, es muy amable necesita el credito para poder comprar materia prima por mayor y asi poder obtener mayores ingresos, es casada y tiene 2 hijos los cuales estan estudiando.  Ana, su negocio es la venta de golosinas como ser, Tajaditas de platano, tacos, yuca, pollo y refrescos todos los dias ella comienza desde las 7:00 am hasta las 9: 00 pm, es una señora muy conocida en la zona por su amabilidad con los clientes cuenta con 19 años de tener su negocio, con esto ha logrado construir su casa que es muy grande, su esposo labora como Mecanico de aviones, el negocio cuenta con sillas y mesas para la comodidad de las personas que van a comer alli, ya tiene clientes fijos que les vende desayunos y almuerzos, esta bien ubicada ya que es en la calle principal de la Col. Nueva Esperanza y es muy transitado por los alumnos de la escuela y colegio que esta muy cerca. Ella necesita el credito para poder comprar productos al por mayor y lograr precios mas bajos. Delmy, es una mujer joven, trabajadora y con muchas ganas de superarse ya que hace un año se graduo como Enfermera, ella cuenta con un pequeño negocio de variedades para uso femenino como ser, lapiz labial, delineadores, colas, ganchos, sombras, cremas, calsetas, aritos, pulseras, asi mismo vende productos por catalogo como ser, cremas , lociones, shampoo, jabones, desodorantes, cuenta con muchas clientas ya que ella tiene una vitrina grande frente a su casa que esta ubicada en una de las calles de acceso a la colonia Venezuela y asi mismo sus amigas y compañeras del centro de salud de la comunidad, tiene quince años de tener su negocio, su esposo labora como mecanico, tienen cinco hijos de los cuales tres ya estan terminando la Universidad y dos estan en la escuela, necesita el dinero para comprar productos como ser vajillas, cremas, perfumes, sandalias, adornos ya que en el mes de mayo se celebra en nuestro pais el dia de la Madre y sus clientas ya le han hecho algunos encargos.
texts.en:
Faith and Hope is a group of women who get along well, sociable neighbors and relatives. They live in the Nueva Esperanza and Venezuela neighborhoods that are very near each other. Wendy, a young woman working for one year, has a small stand which she opens early, by 7:00 AM until midday at 1:00. She returns to open again at 3:00 PM and closes at 6:00 PM. Her business is located very strategically in front of the soccer field and near the Community Health Center. She sells snacks like potato chips, enchiladas, tacos and also the most preferred by customers - shaved ices of coffee and blackberry. On Saturdays she sells the most because a lot of people come to the field. She is very friendly and needs credit to buy ingredients wholesale and thus earn more income. She is married and has 2 children who are students. Ana's business is selling snacks like banana chips, tacos, yucca, chicken, and soft drinks. Every day she starts at 7:00 AM and works until 9:00 PM. She ia a very well known woman in the area for her friendly manner with her clients. She has had the business for 19 years, and has been able to build a large house. Her husband works as a airplane mechanic. The business has chairs and tables for the comfort of the people that go there to eat. She has regular clients to whom she sells breakfast and lunch. She is well located in the main street of Nueva Esperanza which is well travelled by the students of the nearby school and high school. She needs credit to be able to buy products wholesale at lower proices. Delmy is a young woman, hardworking and eager to progress since it is one year ago that she graduated as a nurse. She has a small business selling a variety of products for feminine use such as lipstick, eye liners, adhesives, hooks, shadows, creams, earrings, and bracelets. She also sells products by catalog such as creams, lotions, shampoo, soaps, and deodorants. She has many clients and she has a big window in the front of her house which is located on one of the streets providing access to the Venezuela neighborhood and likewise to her friends and the community health center. She has had this business for fifteen years. Her husband works as a mechanic. They have five children of whom three are now completing the University and two are still in school. She needs the money to buy products such as tableware, creams, perfumes, sandals, and ornaments since in the month of May Mother's Day is celebrated in our country and her clients already have already placed some orders..

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase green bananas, cabbage, salsa, chicken, meat, soft drinks, vegetables, condiments, cups, plates, ornaments, tableware, perfumes, creams

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Antonio

texts.es:
Trabajaba como obrero, pero no le alcanzaba para los gastos, empezo vendiendo entre sus amistades, lentes, mas adelante observo que los globos eran muy vendidos y tambien comenzo con la venta de ellos, de ahi, surgio el ingreso extra que tanto esperaba,puso su negocio en una calle llamada Morelos en Monterrey N,L. que es muy visitada, y a hora pide el apoyo para la compra de mercancia ya que ha tenido buenas ventas, solo que no le alcanza para surtir mucho mas.

Esta actividad a la que se ha dedicado hace 18 años es el sustento de el y su familia, el espiritu de emprendedor lo ha echo que ahora se encuentre dia tras dia, vendiendo sus articulos y asi sostendiendo a su familia.
texts.en:
He worked as a laborer, but this did not meet his expenses, so he began to sell sunglasses among his friends. Much later he saw that balloons were very sell able and also began to sell them, and from there, his extra income surged as he expected. He located his business to a street called Morelos in Monterrey N.L. which is much visited, and now he asks for support for the purchase of merchandise seeing as though he has good sales, but he cannot meet the cost of stocking much more. He has been dedicated this work for 18 years and it is the sustenance of him and his family. The entrepreneurial spirit send him out and now one encounters him, day after day, selling his items and thus providing for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Donna Yates, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise for resale

loans.name: Santos Maria

texts.es: Doña Santos tiene 49 años de edad  ella vive en una ciudad de comayaguela que se llama Peña vieja, es una zona que esta bien poblada de pavimento las casas esta en forma continua cuentan con todos los servicios publicos. Doña Santos ha tenido su pequeño negocio por 30 años, ella compra el maiz la leña, maseca en pulperias, y las vende en su casa, asi mismo entrega doscientos lempiras diarios en una Casa de Beneficiencia Aldeas S.O.S. le pagan mensual seis mil lempiras por una ganancia mensual de $ 300,00 ya que es una buena opcion ya ella puede ver su ganacia mensual, ella se ha dedicado toda su vida a la venta de tortillas, ella tomo un bus para irlas a entregar es muy querida por la gente, a ella le ayuda sus hijas por las mañanas ya que por las tardes va a la universidad, invirtio el prestamo anterior en comprar maiz, leña al por mayor asi puede bajar los gastos ya que puede ir a comprar a un mercado local y gastar menos, ella necesita nuestro apoyo para comprar maiz,leña maseca de nuevo ya que quiere invertir mas, ella vive con su suegra  que es una sra.muy agradable de 80 años con su esposo y sus dos hijas ya que el sueño de la cliente es ver a sus hijas graduadas,me agrado pasar una momento agradable con doña Santos
texts.en:
Doña Santos is 49 years old. She lives in a town of Comayaguela called Peña Vieja which is a densely populated area, paved, the houses are built closely and have all public services. Doña Santos has had her small business for 30 years, she buys corn, firewood, and corn flour at local stores and sells from her house. She also delivers merchandise for two hundred "lempiras" (local currency) daily to a "Casa de Beneficiencia Aldeas S.O.S." She is paid six thousand "lempiras" monthly allowing earnings of $300.00. This is a good option as she can see her monthly earnings. She has been selling tortillas all her life, she takes a bus to make the deliveries. She is very beloved by the people. Her daughters help her in the mornings as they attend university in the afternoons. A previous loan was invested in buying corn and firewood in bulk to lower costs as she can buy at a local market and spend less. She needs our support to buy corn, firewood and corn flour as the wants to invest more. She lives with her mother-in-law, who is a very nice 80-year-old lady, her husband and her two daughters. It is her dream to see her daughters graduate. I spent a pleasant moment with doña Santos.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase firewood, corn, and corn flour.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Hermila

texts.es:
Comenzo con la venta de delineador para ojos, pero la gente empezo a pedir mas variedad, como perfumes, comenzo con amigos, vecinos y ahora quiere comenzar con los perfumes de este catalogo jafra.

Ella es un gran apoyo para su esposo, ya que con los ingresos que gana, mantienen a sus tres hijos de 10, 9  y 6 años, que como padres les brindan el estudios y cubren sus necesidades.

ahora comenzara con este producto que se lo han solicitado mucho, apoyemos esta gran emprendedora.
texts.en:
Doña Hermila started selling eyeliner, but people started to demand more variety, such as perfumes. She started with friends, neighbours, and now she wants to begin selling perfumes from the Jafra Catalog.

She represents an important support for her husband, as the income is to maintain their three children, 10, 9, and 6 years of age. As parents they give them schooling and cover their needs.

Let us support this great entrepreneur as she is starting to sell this new highly demanded product.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy goods

loans.name: Jeane

texts.en: Mrs. Jeane O. is hardworking and determined.  She is from Tudela, Misamis Occidental, and is 36 years old.  She is married and blessed with three children, two of which are in secondary school and one is in elementary school.  Her husband is a farmer. In order to cope with the abject poverty that is inevitable to the family, she started selling snacks to neighbors, relatives, and friends. Because she did not have enough capital to start a sari-sari store, she joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative last April to access loan credit for additional capital to be used in the construction of a small stall. Her and her husband’s heart and desire is to send their children to college and witness them successful in their lives in the future.

loans.use: additional capital for sari-sari store

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Mrs. Lourdes E. started her sari-sari store business with the very minimal capital of 5,000 PHP. Her customers are neighbors, friends and relatives. She is 44-years old and lives in Tudela, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Lourdes is married to a farmer and blessed with five children. Three of them are working already, one is married and the last is still studying.

Last July, 2008, she became a member of Paglaum MPC and now she is able to acquire additional capital for her business. She is coping well with the challenges. It requires hard work and patience. Her aspiration is to have a bigger store and to be able to sell farm fertilizers and feeds.

loans.use: Additional capital for a sari-sari store

loans.name: Enedina

texts.en: Enedina C. is 47-years old, married to a motorcycle driver and she is from Tudela, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She has been a member of Paglaum MPC since March, 2005. She has demonstrated excellent performance in loan repayments. Now, she is applying for a loan of 6,000 PHP to purchase hog feed and vitamins. She hopes that someday she can own a traveling boar that will augment their household income and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase hog feed

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
J. Luz has requested a loan of 20,000 PHP to acquire a new fishing boat for her fishing business. She is 52-years old, married and blessed with three children. Among the three children, two are still studying. Her husband is a carpenter.

She has been a member of Paglaum MPC for almost nine years under the microfinance program. She is reliable and active in all Coop activities. In fact, she is the chief of her center. She wants to improved her business and increase her income so that she can educate her children.

loans.use: To acquire a new fishing boat

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Olailagi

texts.en: Olailagi T., 73, is married with six children.  She has many years of experience in the taro and banana plantation business. She sells to the village community and general public, two days per week. She has had five previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~$110 US).  SPBD loans are Olailagi’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase tools and equipment such as spade, wheelbarrow, bush knives, water hose and rake

loans.name: Akenese

texts.en: Akenese M., 42, is married with four children.  She has many years of experience in the taro and banana plantation business. She sells to the village community and general public, three days per week. She has had six previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 tala (~$110 US).  SPBD loans are Akenese’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for home improvements and school fees.

loans.use: To buy cement, iron roofing, electric chainsaw and pay school fees

loans.name: Tasi

texts.en:
Tasi S., 50, is married with four children. She has many years of experience in her taro (a root vegetable) and banana plantation business. She sells three days per week to the village community and to the general public. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (approximately $100).

Tasi has two previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy fence wire, containers for water storage, bushknives and an electric chainsaw

loans.name: Tima

texts.en:
Tima P., 30, is married with four children. She has many years of experience in her banana plantation business. She sells three days per week to the village community and to the general public. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (approximately $115). Part of her loan will be used for school fees.

Tima has five previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, weedkiller ,pesticides. bushknives and fence wire and to pay school fees

loans.name: Seleni

texts.en: Seleni A., 38, is married and has 3 children.  She has 5 years of experience in the sewing business. She sells to the general public 6 days per week. She has had 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Samoan Tala (~145 USD).  SPBD loans are Seleni’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine, thread, needles and material.

loans.name: Samoa

texts.en: Samoa P., 64, is married and has 10 children.  She has 10 years of experience in the vegetable business. She sells to the village community & to the general public 3 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Samoan Tala (~125 USD).  SPBD loans are Samoa’s only access to capital as she does not qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase vegetable seeds (cucumber, cabbages, pumpkin), gloves, a rake and a wheelbarrow.

loans.name: Sou

texts.en: Sou T., 23, is married and has 1 child.  She has 5 years of experience in the grocery business. She sells to the village community & to the general public 2 days per week. She has had 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Samoan Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Sou’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase laundry powder, box of noodles, clorox, sack of flour, rice, sugar, box of herring, beverages and ice cream.

loans.name: Siliua

texts.en:
Siliua K. F., 39, is married with five children. She has four years of experience in her elei design business (a style of cloth printing which is unique to Samoa and is used in much of Samoan clothing). She sells to the village community and to the general public two days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (approximately $80).

Siliua has six previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase elei board, colour paints, material and a sewing machine

loans.name: Faapaia

texts.en: Faapaia P., 25, is married and has 3 children.  She has 4 years of experience in the furniture shop business. She sells to the village community & to the general public 3 days per week. She has had 6 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Samoan Tala (~208 USD).  SPBD loans are Faapaia’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase lumber, clear vanish , painting , plywood, nails and a hammer for furniture business.

loans.name: Masae

texts.en: Masae M., 28, is married and has 5 children.  She has many years of experience in the grocery business. She sells to the village community & to the general public. She has had 7 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Samoan Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Masae’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase a box of noodles, soy sauce, box of herring, toilet rolls, twisties, lollies, beverages and laundry powder.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria S., 20, is single and has no children.  She has 2 years of experience in the canteen business. She sells food to the school children 5 days per week. She has not borrowed from SPBD before. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Samoan Tala (~83 USD). SPBD loans are Maria’s only access to capital because she does not qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase bread, butter, tinned tuna, eggs and plastic wrap.

loans.name: Anatalia

texts.en:
Anatalia M. is 49 years old and a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative from Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is married with no children. She is very industrious, managing their hog-raising business while her husband works in carpentry.

The management and development of their business is doing well. As she said, "In a business, there is always ups and down, sometimes it gains profits and sometimes it is losing."

Now she sees a good opportunity to expand their business. She is requesting PHP7,000 from Paglaum MPC, a Kiva partner, to buy feed and vitamins for her hogs. She deeply hopes to own a bigger concrete piggery someday.

loans.use: Purchase feed and vitamins

loans.name: Shanna

texts.en: Shanna A. F., 21, is married and has 1 child.  She has 2 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village community & to the general public 3 days per week. She has had 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Samoan Tala (~125 USD). SPBD loans are Shanna’s only access to capital because she does not qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase gramoxones, pesticides, a wheelbarrow and weed killer for farming.

loans.name: Ceferina

texts.en:
Mrs. Ceferina P. is 59 years old, separated, and blessed with 5 children – all of them have finished their schooling and have their own job. Selling of fish is her primary activity and the source of household income.

Mrs P. has been the sole breadwinner of the family. Because of her determination and hard work, her daughter is now a certified public accountant. Now, she needs additional capital of Php5,000 in order to sustain and maintain her regular customers. She's planning to own a stall in the market and to have savings for future needs.

loans.use: Additional capital for fish selling.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Mrs. Susan D. is 50 years old and a resident at Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is blessed with 5 children. Two of them are married and three have their own job. Her husband is a carpenter and also helps in farming, specifically growing cassava, which is their primary activity.

They own a little parcel of land, and part of it is mortgaged. Now they plan to redeem it. Mrs D. has been a member of Paglaum MPC since March 2005 with an excellent loan repayment performance.

She is applying for Php20,000 to buy farm fertilizers and pesticides, while part of it will be used to redeem the mortgaged land. She dreams that some day, she will be the one supplying cassava in the market and have enough finances at her age.

loans.use: To purchase farm fertilizer and pesticides, and help repay a mortgage on her land.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Mrs. Evelyn O. is 33 years old and married with 3 children. Two of her children are in primary school and the third is a newborn baby. She is from Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental and her husband is a carpenter.

She has been a member of Paglaum MPC since March 2005 and is now on her 12th loan cycle, seeking Php20,000 for additional capital for her sari-sari store. She will use it to buy stock such as laundry items, seasonings, goodies, toiletries and other household items.

With her previous loans, she has demonstrated an outstanding loan repayment record. She aims to have a successful business with a concrete store and to send their children to college to have a good future.

loans.use: Additional capital for sari-sari (general) store.

loans.name: Ashura

texts.en:
Ashura is a food seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to the Tawakal loan group (group code 2041). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $60. She works at her business daily.

She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business, like rice and flour. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Ashura is married and has three children, who are 20, 15, and 4.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business, like rice and flour.

loans.name: Subeha

texts.en:
Subeha has been a juice and ice cream seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for one year. She belongs to the Subira ina mpaka loan group (group code 2013). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $15. Every day she works at her business for eight hours.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy some sugar, fruit, and flavor for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money.

Subeha is 28 years old and married with a three year old child.

loans.use: To buy some sugar, fruit, and flavor for her business.

loans.name: Uvumilivu Group

texts.en:
Halima has owned a small restaurant in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for one year. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. Every day she works at her business for eight hours.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more flour, sugar, rice, beans, and tomatoes for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money.

Halima is 40 years old and married with six children who are ages 15, 9, 7, 4, 3, and 1. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member Singa, a woman who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, flour, rice, beans, and tomatoes for her restaurant.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace has owned a small grocery store in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for six years. She belongs to the Semtema B south loan group (group code 2021). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. Every day, she works at her business for eleven hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more grocery items to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Grace is 30 years old and married with two children who are ages 16 and 12.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items for her store.

loans.name: Kanchi

texts.en:
Mrs. Kanchi M. is a grocery shopkeeper in the village of Thecho. She opened her grocery store six years ago. She sells different types of grocery goods. She opened her grocery store to improve the living standards of her family.

Due to lack of money, she cannot upgrade her shop. So she is requesting a loan for Rs 25000.00 to buy various grocery goods.

Mrs. Kanchi M. lives with her husband and two children. Her husband Mr. Binod M. is a taxi driver. She has one son and one daughter. Her son is studying in grade 7 and daughter is studying in grade 10.

loans.use: To buy goods for her grocery store.

loans.name: Emmy

texts.en:
Emmy has owned a small salon in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for two months. She belongs to the Jipe moyo loan group (group code 2088). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. Every day, she works at her business for eight hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can improve her business by buying more salon items, like weaving supplies, hair treatments, artificial items, hair condition, and shampoo. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Emmy is 32 years old, married, and has two children who are ages nine years and four months. She also takes care of one additional dependent.

loans.use: To buy more supplies for her salon.

loans.name: Wastara Group

texts.en:
Namboto has owned a small charcoal and firewood store in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She belongs to the Wastara loan group (group code 2006). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $70. Every day she works at her business for eight hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can  buy more charcoal and firewood to add her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Namboto is 33 years old and married with three children who are ages 15 years, 12 years, and 9 months.  She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member Halima. Halima her own small business selling clothes in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewod to add her current stock.

loans.name: Sangita

texts.en:
Sangita K. is a resident of Sainbu-Bhaishipati, Lalitpur. She lives with her husband, Mr. Bashu Dev K., two sons, and a daughter. Her older son is studying in BBS 3rd year and also works in a small office. Her younger son is studying in grade 9. Her daughter is studying in BAC 2nd year and is also a teacher. Both Mr. and Mrs. K. are engaged in poultry and agricultural farming. They opened their poultry farm more than ten years ago. They buy all the small chickens and food grain to feed the chickens from dealers.

They are successfully running their poultry farm and earn a good profit but a few months ago they faced huge losses. All their 1000 chickens died at once and so they are facing lots of problems in their business. To overcome this problem, Mrs. K. is requesting a loan for Rs 30000.00 to continue their poultry business. She will use the loan to buys small chickens and food.

loans.use: To buys chickens and feed.

loans.name: Leluli

texts.en:
Leluli has owned a small charcoal and firewood store in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for five years. She belongs to the Uaminifu loan group (group code 2004). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $175. Each day, she works at her business for eight hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and firewood to add her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money.

Leluli is 50 years old and married with five children who are ages 34, 32, 31, 25, and 20.

loans.use: To buy more stock of charcoal and firewood.

loans.name: Wapendanao Group

texts.en:
Tatu has been a soft drinks seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She currently earns very little monthly profit. Each day, she works at her business for eight hours.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more soda to add to her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Tatu is 25 years old and married with a two year old child. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members Rehema and Time. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more soda to add her current stock.

loans.name: Nanda Kumari

texts.en:
Nanda Kumari M. lives in Thecho village. She lives in a single family residence with her husband and two children. She has one son, who is studying in grade 6, and one daughter, who is studying in grade 9.

Both Mrs. M. and Mr. Krishna Bahadur M. are engaged in making different types of brass religious statues. They make different types of statues according to the demands of their customers. They also receive orders from dealers. 

Mrs. Nanda Kumari M. has already taken a loan from Kiva and repaid it. With that previous loan, she was able to buy various types of raw materials for their work. Now she is requesting a loan of  NPR 30000 to buy additional raw materials necessary for their work.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for making brass religious statues

loans.name: Maendeleo Group

texts.en:
Asia has been a clothes and bites (maandazi) seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 11 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $70. Every day she works at her business for 8 hours.

Asia is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes, flour, and cooking oil for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money.

Asia is 31 years old and married. She has four children, ages 15, 14, 12 and 10. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Sada, who also has her own small business of selling fish in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale and more flour  and cooking oil to cook bites

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mwajuma has been a clothes seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 1 year. She belongs to the Msimamo loan group (group code 2015). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $70. Every day she works at her business for 8 hours.

She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes to add her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Mwajuma is 22 years old and married. She has two children, ages 6 and 3.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to add her current stock.

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita P. is a resident of Sepac, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She has been a good member of Paglaum Cooperative for almost four years and obtaining a loan helps her a lot in her daily needs. It also helps her to send her children to school.

This, her sixth loan cycle, amounts to Php 6,500, and is intended for corn production. It is her dream to buy fertilizers for her corn plantation for a good harvest.

She's is also thankful to Paglaum micro-finance for their programs and services that help the poor people and encourages them to work hard for their future. They wish to have a better living in the future and be able to give their children a good future.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her corn plantation

loans.name: Crisilda

texts.en:
Crisilda O. is 33 years old and married to Romiel O.. They are blessed with two children and live in the town of Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. Her husband is a driver and receives an average monthly income of Php 9,000.

Crisilda’s business was already in existance before she become a member of Paglaum Coop. She is now one year into her membership. She loaned Php 15,000 for additional capital for her food-vending business . Her customers are her neighbors, friends and relatives. She is a good and hardworking mother. Paglaum help her business grow and to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy stocks of pork, vegetables, fruit and spices for her business

loans.name: Candilaria

texts.en:
Candilaria B., 59 years old, is a widow with three children, all of them married. They live in Panalsalan, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is an active member of Paglaum Coop and has been sealed with MIGS (Member in Good Standing) since she began her membership.

Candilaria loaned Php 15,000 for additional capital for her existing seafood-vending business. She sells during market day at their location and also in neighboring towns and cities.

She is grateful to Paglaum and Kiva lenders who support her and make her business more progressive.

loans.use: To buy more seafood products to sell

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Mrs. Leonora E., 47 years old, is married and blessed with five children. One of them is already married and four are still studying.

Leonora is a member of good standing of PAGLAUM COOP under its PDPLP program. She is a good member because she has never committed a default of her weekly obligation. Now she has obtained a loan of Php 6,000 as additional capital for her proposed project which is rice production.

Leonora tries to cope up with her obligations like savings, CBU (Capital Build Up) and insurance, hoping that it will give the best return in the future and also to their children.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her proposed rice-growing business

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma has owned a small market in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for one year. She belongs to umoja ubarikiti group loan (Group code 2100). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $70. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to add to her current stock and improve her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Salma is 37 years old, married, and has three children: ages 12, 9 and 6. She also cares for one additional dependent.

loans.use: To buy more items to add to her current stock to improve  her business

loans.name: Jina

texts.en:
Jina is 28 years old and married, with a 10-year-old child. She has been a dressmaker in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She works at her business for eight hours every day and earns an average monthly profit of $25.

She belongs to the R'haigawanyiki group loan (group code 2080) and is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania in order to buy more items for her business. She hopes that this loan will help her increase profits and grow her business so that she can save money for future use.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Herminigilda

texts.en:
Life is what we make it! That’s what Herminigilda says. No matter what we want, we have to work for it! Everything she does is for the sake of her family. She is 56 years old, married and lives in Dullan, Aloran, Misamis Occidental.

Her husband is a refrigerator technician. First, he was employed by a shop where he received a salary of only 3,000 PHP per month. She convinced him to open their own shop, using a loan from the Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative as capital.

Their refrigeration business is doing well, and they are earning more than expected. They have gained more customers because of the quality of the services they provide. They repair and repaint refrigerators and provide door-to-door service.

She aims to expand her business and acquire technology for an air-conditioning business. She also hopes that all of her children can finish their studies in order to have successful careers in the future.

loans.use: Additional capital for her refrigeration shop.

loans.name: Yataka Moyo Group

texts.en:
Sakina has sold snacks in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for one year. She works at her business for eight hours every day and currently earns an average monthly profit of $80.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more flour, cooking oil and sugar to add to her current stock. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase profits and grow her business so that she can save money for future use.

Sakina is 30 years old, married, and has four children between the ages of 2 and 6. She will share this loan with her fellow group members (also pictured): Hasina, Khadija, Rehema and Mayasa. Each of these women has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more flour, sugar and cooking oil to add her current stock.

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia K. is married with two children. For six years, she has worked as a trader selling fried fish. She also prepares food for sale in Siwdo. Her husband is employed as a farmer. Afia uses her income to pay for the various expenses of her family such as school fees and utility bills.

Afia will use this loan to purchase additional oil, fish and other foodstuffs for cooking and selling. She plans to reinvest the new profits from her expanded business back into her trade.

loans.use: To purchase additional oil, fish and other foodstuffs for cooking and selling

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Since 2001, Rose C. has worked as a trader selling various foodstuffs at Dwomo Primary School near Shama Junction. She sells food such as cooked rice, palm nut soup and beans. She is married with three children and received an education through junior high school. While Rose works as a trader, her husband is employed as a painter. She is responsible for assisting her husband in the upkeep of the family and also for paying various family expenses.

Rose’s loan will be used to increase her capital base to buy more foodstuffs for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a home for her aged mother and for her children.

loans.use: To increase her capital base and buy more foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort B. is divorced with four children and has received an education through primary school. Since 2005 she has worked as a trader selling oranges at Tomo School near Shama Junction. Comfort uses her income to pay for the upkeep of the house because she is the sole provider for her family.

Comfort will use the loan to purchase more oranges to sell and with the new profits from her expanded business, Comfort plans to open a bank account and start saving her money.

loans.use: To purchase more oranges to sell

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas K. is married and takes care of her sister’s child. She received an education through primary school. Since 2008, Dorcas has worked as a trader, selling small provisions such as nuts, gari (ginger) and sugar at Dwomo Primary School near Shama Junction, Ghana.  

While Dorcas works as a trader, her husband is employed as a mason. She uses her income to pay for her family’s electricity bill. Dorcas will use the loan to increase her capital, in order to buy more provisions for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Dorcas plans to save and build a house for her family.

loans.use: Dorcas will use the loan to buy more provisions for resale.

loans.name: Maame Aba

texts.en:
Since 2002 Maame Aba W. has worked as a trader selling oil at Sekondi Tadi near Shama Junction. She is married with three children and has received no formal education. While she works as a trader, her husband is employed as a farmer. Maame Aba is responsible for helping assist her husband with the family’s various expenses and with the upkeep of the household.

Maame Aba’s loan will be used to purchase additional oil for sale and she hopes to start saving the new profits from her expanded business. The containers shown in the photo are what she buys the oil in. She then sell the oil in smaller quantities.

loans.use: To purchase additional oil for sale

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en: Since 1994, Deborah A. has worked as a baker at Kojokrom near Shama Junction, selling bread. She is married with three children. She received an education through senior high school. Deborah uses her income to pay for various family expenses, particularly the water bill. She will use this loan to purchase additional bread baking necessities and therefore produce more goods. With the new profits from her expanded business, Deborah plans to start saving her money at the bank and also to build a house for her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional bread baking necessities

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth Q. is married with four children and has received an education through junior high school. Since 1991 she has worked as a petty trader, selling corn at Kojokrom near Shama Junction. Her husband works as a corn dealer. Elizabeth uses her income to support her family by providing housekeeping money.

Elizabeth will use the loan to purchase additional corn for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business she plans to pay for her children’s school fees and also continue building their new home.

Elizabeth's warehouse was very dark so she was asked, for the photo, to take a few samples to show what she sells.

loans.use: To purchase additional corn to sell

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en: Millicent A. works as a baker selling bread at Kojokram near Shama Junction, which she has done since 2001. She is single with two children. Millicent received an education through senior high school. She is responsible for paying some of her family’s various expenses, such as the light bill. Her loan will be used to purchase additional flour which she will use to bake more bread.  She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house for her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional flour for bread making

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua A. works as a petty trader, selling charcoal at Kojokrom, near Shama Junction. Ekua has been in business since 2005. She is married with three children and her husband is employed as a mason. Ekua is responsible for paying her family’s various household expenses, particularly the water bill. Her loan will be used to purchase additional charcoal for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house for her family.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal for resale

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Since 2006, Ama A. has worked as a trader selling tomatoes, red oil and garden eggs at Sekondi Market near Shama Junction. She is a widow with four children and has received no formal education. Ama assumes full financial responsibility for the household and is the main provider for her family. Her loan will be used to purchase additional goods, especially onions, which she will then resell. Ama hopes to use her newly gained profits to add to the capital of her business and ensure her continued success.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods, especially onions

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Since 1984, Veronica A. has worked as a trader selling tomatoes at Sekondi Market near Shama Junction. She is a widow with two children and has received an education through senior high school. Because her husband is deceased, she is the sole provider for her children and primarily responsible for the upkeep of the house. Her loan will be used to purchase tomatoes in bulk which she will then resell. Veronica hopes to save some of the new profits and also to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase tomatoes in bulk

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary T. is married with four children and has no formal education. Since 2002, she has worked as a trader selling goods such as kenkey (fermented white maize food) and groundnut paste at Sekondi Market near Shama Junction. Her husband is employed as a cold store operator, selling frozen fish and other types of meat. Mary uses her income to assist her husband in paying for the family’s housekeeping expenses. Mary will use the loan to purchase additional foodstuffs for selling. Mary plans to save the new profits she gains from her expanded business in order to ensure her continued success.

loans.use: To purchase additional foodstuffs for selling

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace works as a hairdresser and also sells hair products at Shama Junction, which she has done since 2007. She is married with three children and received an education through junior high school. Her husband works as a driver. Grace uses her income to pay for her family’s various expenses, primarily clothing. She will use the loan to purchase additional hair products for resale and also to use on her customers' hair. With the new profits from her expanded business, Grace plans to purchase land on which she will build a house.

loans.use: To purchase additional hair products

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Since 2007, Esther N. has worked as a trader at Kojokram, near Shama Junction, selling goods such as beef and charcoal.  She is married with three children and received an education through senior high school. While Esther works as a trader, her husband is employed at the Tarkwa gold mines. Esther is responsible for assisting her husband in paying for the upkeep of the household. Her loan will be used to purchase additional charcoal and other goods for resale and she hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal and other goods for resale

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha A. is a petty trader selling provisions at Shama Junction. She is married with two children and received an education through primary school.  While Martha works as a trader, her husband is employed as a mason. She is financially responsible for her family’s various expenses, primarily to ensure the upkeep of the household. Her loan will be used to purchase additional provisions and secondhand goods for selling. Martha hopes to use the new profits from her business to support her husband in the construction of their home.

loans.use: To purchase additional provisions and secondhand goods for selling

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica B. is divorced with three children and received an education through senior high school. Since 2006 Veronica has worked as a petty trader at Shama Junction selling oil. She uses her income to pay for her family’s various expenses including the water and light bills as well as rent.

Veronica will use the loan to purchase additional oil for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Veronica plans to support her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase additional oil for resale

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en:
Charlotte O. is married with three children and received an education through primary school. Since 1999 she has worked as a petty trader selling secondhand clothing at Shama Junction. While Charlotte works as a trader, her husband is employed as a fisherman. Charlotte uses her income to pay for her family’s water bill.

Charlotte will use the loan to purchase additional clothing to sell. With her newly gained profits, she plans to reinvest in her business to continue the expansion of her trade.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothing to sell

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Since 2005, Nancy E. has worked as a petty trader selling clothing and provisions at Sekondi Market near Shama Junction. She is married with three children and received an education through senior high school. Nancy is responsible for helping to pay for her family’s financial expenses, especially housekeeping money.

Her loan will be used to purchase for her business various provisions such as rice, soup and oil as well as clothing. She hopes to use her newly gained profits to reinvest and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothing and various provisions such as rice, soup and oil

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es: Hilda tiene 37 años, vive con Jesús su esposo, y su hijo Yomar de 6 años en su casa propia. Desde hace uno año, junto a su esposo, se dedica a la compra y venta de madera, para cubrir los gastos de su pequeño Yomar, nombre que le pusieron en su honor a su negocio, el cual les arroja bueno resultados, gracias a todo el empeño que le ponen, ya que Jesús viaja constantemente a otras provincias para dejar los pedidos que le hacen, resultándole muy rentable siendo sus servicios son muy demandados y obteniendo un buen dinero de todas sus ventas, mientras Hilda es quien administra el negocio. A ella le gusta su negocio, y aunque a veces hay cosas feas, como que la gente no paga a tiempo sus pedidos y tienen que estar detrás de para que les paguen, siempre le ha puesto mucha energía y ganas a su trabajo. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP y se compromete a ser muy puntual y responsable en todos sus pagos. Con el dinero solicitado comprará mayor cantidad de madera para aumentar sus ventas.	¿Qué es lo que comprará con este dinero?
texts.en:
Hilda id 37 years old. She lives with Jesus, her husband, and her son, Yomar, who is 6 years old, in her own house. For the past year, together with her husband, she has been buying and selling timber in order to cover the expenses of her youngster, Yomar, name also given to their business in his honor and it it providing good results thanks to their effort as Jesus constantly travels to other provinces delivering orders. Their services are in high demand and it is a good business and they earn well. While he travels, Hilda is in charge of the business. She enjoys her business and even if sometimes there are ugly issues when customers do not pay punctually and they have to be on their back to make them pay, she has always provided energy and passion to her work. This is her first loan with MFP and she is committed to repay punctually and responsably. With the money requested she will buy more timber in order to increase sales.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: Maria tiene 46 años, vive con su pareja y su pequeño bebé, por el cual trabaja arduamente con el sueño de brindarle todo lo mejor. Se dedica al alquiler de lavadoras, negocio en el cual incursionó hace 4 años, siendo un negocio muy rentable, ya que por la zona en la que ella vive no existe este servicio, siendo muy favorable. Su labor consiste en atender los pedidos de los clientes que se acercan a su casa solicitándole el alquiler de alguna de sus tres lavadoras, trasportándolas en una pequeña carretilla al lugar destinado. El negocio va “viento en popa” y los pedidos de alquiler son cada vez mayores, dado que tiene un hijo pequeño que cuidar, puede desempeñar este trabajo en su casa, sin quitarle mucho tiempo. Por otro lado, el peligro es que sus máquinas puedan sufrir algunas averías, felizmente, hasta ahora todos sus clientes siempre han sido muy cuidadosos y no se le ha presentado mayor dificultad. Con el tiempo a María le gustaría tener una lavandería con más de 7 lavadoras para poder efectuar este trabajo desde su casa y que las lavadoras ya no tengan que salir. Esta es la primera vez que tiene un préstamo individual con MFP, prometiendo ser muy puntual en todos sus pagos. Con el dinero solicitado dará la cuota inicial para adquirir otra lavadora y así incrementar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
María is 46 years old and lives with her partner and her small baby, for whom she works hard with the dream of providing her all the best. She rents out washing machines, a business she started four years ago. It is a very profitable business, because the area where she lives does not have this service, which makes hers very favorable. Her work involves attending to orders from her customers who come to her house asking to rent one of the three washing machines, and transporting them in a small truck to the appropriate place. The business is doing very well and rental orders are increasing. As she has a small son to care for, she can take care of this work from home, without taking much time. On the other hand, the risk is that her machines could experience some trouble-- fortunately, so far all her customers have always been very careful and she has not faced any major problems. Over time, María would like to have a laundromat with more than seven washing machines to be able to take care of this work from home and so that the machines would not have to leave. This is the first time she is receiving an individual loan from MFP, and is promising to be very punctual with all her payments. With the money requested she will put a down payment on the purchase of another washing machine and thus increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Kerrie Lenhart, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a new washing machine

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es: Pedro tiene 54 años, vive con su esposa y sus tres hijas, las cuales se dedican a la elaboración  y venta de artesanías, siendo una familia muy unida. Él se dedica a la refacción de autos, realiza el planchado y pintado de ellos para dejarlos óptimos y puedan transitar por las calles, aprendió desde muy joven a realizar este oficio, el cual dejó de lado por un tiempo para dedicarse al locutorio que puso en su propia vivienda. Debido a que sus hijas empezaron a realizar artesanías en su casa, tuvieron la idea de que ellas podrían atender el locutorio mientras su papá retomaba en su oficio para obtener ingresos adicionales. Para Pedro, esta actividad, más que un trabajo es un pasatiempo que le gusta realizar, claro que esto no significa que sea fácil, ya que demanda de mucho esfuerzo físico, el cual está acostumbrado a realizar. Para el futuro espera implementar su propio taller de planchado y pintado de autos y así dedicarse de neto a ello. Es la primera vez Pedro tiene un préstamo con MFP, y promete ser muy puntual en toda las cancelaciones de sus cuotas. Con el dinero solicitado comprará algunas herramientas que le están haciendo falta para desarrollar mejor su trabajo, y la otra parte la invertirá en el negocio de sus hijas para comprar materiales (mostacillas, hilos, alambres, etc.) para ayudarlas con la producción de sus artículos.
texts.en:
Pedro is 54 years old and lives with his wife and three daughters, who make and sell handicrafts. They are a very close family. Pedro restores cars, repairing dents and repainting so that they are in optimal condition for the road. He learned this trade from a young age, but he left it for a while to run a telephone booth in his home. When his daughters began making crafts at home they had the idea to take over the management of the phone booth so that their father could return to working with cars and make more money.

For Pedro, his work is more than a job, but an activity that he really enjoys. The work is not easy, as it demands a lot of physical exertion, but he is used to the effort. In the future, he would like to have his own auto body repair shop and devote himself completely to it.

This is Pedro's first loan from Microfinanzas PRISMA, and he promises to be punctual with his payments. He will use the money to purchase tools he needs to develop his business. He will also invest in his daughters' business by purchasing items they need to create their products (beads, string, wire, etc.).

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tools and invest in his daughters' business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Roberto

texts.es: Roberto tiene 56 años, es un hombre muy trabajador, tiene su casa propia en el distrito de Ventanilla, donde vive con su esposa y sus hijos. Desde muy joven incursionó en gran cantidad de trabajos, aprendiendo en uno de ellos a conducir, y desde entonces su meta fue tener un carrito propio, es así que con el esfuerzo de muchos años de trabajo logró comprar un camión con el cual trabaja actualmente dedicado al servicio de transporte de carga. El trabajo es duro, ya que suele salir desde tempranas horas de la mañana y terminar muy tarde por la noche, felizmente no está solo, pues tiene a su lado a su esposa, quien es el motor de su hogar y quien lo apoya incondicionalmente, sabe que juntos podrán lograr todos sus objetivos, ya que tienen muchas ganas y siempre ponen lo mejor de sí en cada cosa que hacen. Roberto se encuentra en su primer préstamo con MFP, y promete ser muy puntual en sus pagos, porque sabe que se está comprometiendo con una gran responsabilidad, él agradece a todas las personas que hacen posible su crédito y lo acercan más a sus objetivos. Con el dinero está solicitando refaccionará su camión y dará la cuota inicial para la adquisición de otro camión, el cual le permita mejorar sus ingresos económicos.
texts.en:
Roberto is a very hard-working 56-year-old man. He lives with his wife and children in their own home in the Ventanilla district. He began working when he was very young and has had a variety of jobs. At one of his jobs, he learned to drive, and since then he has had the goal of having his own car. After many years of hard work he was finally able to buy a truck, which he now uses to transport cargo. The work is difficult, as he usually has to leave very early in the morning and finishes late at night. Happily, he doesn't work alone, as his wife is by his side. She is the driving force behind their home, and supports him unconditionally. Roberto knows that together they can achieve all their dreams, as they are very motivated and always do their best in everything they do.

This is Roberto's first loan from Microfinanzas PRISMA, and he promises to be punctual with its repayment. He knows that this is a great responsibility, and he is grateful to all those who are making this loan possible and helping him get closer to his goals. He will use this loan to refurbish his truck and to put a down payment on another one, which will increase his income.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Refurbish his truck

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.es: Evelyn tiene 29 años, vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos en la casa de su suegra. Desde hace 8 años trabaja de manera independiente vendiendo cosméticos, y hace poco comenzó empezó a vender ropa también. Diariamente visita de casa en casa a sus clientes en diferentes lugares de su ciudad. Evelyn reparte sus productos o ropa según solicitud, y luego va cobrando según haya convenido los plazos de pago, estos artículos los compra viajando cada cierto tiempo a diferentes ciudades. Ella misma se propone sus metas de venta porque posee la cualidad de perseverar aunque se sienta muy cansada por las largas caminatas que realiza. Hasta el momento su negocio le ha dado buenos frutos que le permiten ser un sostén más en su hogar y para el futuro su deseo es seguir adelante con este negocio y establecerse en un local comercial o un puesto de ventas. Es la primera vez que Evelyn tiene la experiencia de trabajar en un banco comunal, para ella es un gran desafío, porque ha escuchado que es un trabajo muy comprometido. El dinero que viene solicitando es poder la compra de más mercadería en prendas de vestir y cosméticos.
texts.en:
Evelyn is 29 years old and lives with her husband and two children in her mother-in-law's home. For the last eight years Evelyn has sold cosmetics and recently began selling clothing as well. Every day she goes from house to house visiting her customers in different neighborhoods of the city. Evelyn takes orders for clothing and cosmetics and, once the orders are paid in full, she delivers them. She purchases her merchandise by traveling every so often to different cities. Evelyn creates her own sales goals, since she is very driven despite being exhausted from the long distances she must walk.

So far, Evelyn's business has been successful and has enabled her to provide economic support to her household. She hopes to continue developing this business and one day have a store or stall from which to sell her merchandise. This is the first time that Evelyn has worked with a community bank, and for her it is a great challenge, as she has heard that it is very involved work. She will use the money from this loan to purchase more clothing and cosmetics.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Djatougbé Améyo

texts.fr: Madame zougbédé a appris la couture, n’ayant pas assez de moyens pour ouvrir un atelier de couture, elle s’est lancée en 2007 dans le commerce  de produits d’alimentation générale, elle s’approvisionne dans les marchés de Vogan et de tsévie. Elle veut ajouter à son commerce la vente de Gari qui est faite à base de farine de manioc et  qui se mange avec de la sauce. Elle  sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 20 sacs et pouvoir assurer des frais de  transport. Elle est mariée et à 01 enfant.
texts.en:
Mrs. Zougbédé learned sewing, however, not having sufficient means to open a sewing workshop, she began selling groceries in 2007. She buys her merchandise in the markets of Vogan and Tsévie. She wants to begin selling "gari" as well; "gari" is made of manioc flour and is eaten with stew. She is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 20 sacks and pay for transporting them. She is married and has one child.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of manioc flour for re-sale

loans.name: Carmen Eddy

texts.es:
Carmen es socia del Banco Comunal Bienestar.
Carmen es casada, tiene 52 años y 5 hijos, Carmen viaja a la selva ayacuchana en donde vende abarrotes en general, actividad que realiza junto a su esposo, sus productos los transporta con carro propio, además tiene carros con los cuales realiza transporte de pasajeros.
Carmen necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar.
Carmen sueña con hacer crecer sus negocios y tener una cadena de farmacias.
texts.en:
Carmen is a member of the Bienestar communal bank. She is married, 52 years old and has 5 children. Carmen travels to the Ayacuchana forest where she sells groceries, an activity she does with her husband. The products are transported in their own car and they also have cars that they use as public transport. Carmen needs a loan of 3000 Soles which will be invested in the purchase of rice and sugar. Carmen dreams of growing her business and having a chain of pharmacy stores.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice and sugar

loans.name: Salome Donatilda

texts.es:
Salome es socia del Banco Comunal Bienestar.
Salome es casada, tiene 42 años y 3 hijos, Salome tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, verduras, carnes, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su hija. Además Salome tiene un carro con el cual su esposo realiza transporte de pasajeros a diferentes distritos de la región.
Salome necesita un préstamo de 2100 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar, aceite.
Los sueños de Salome son que sus hijos sean profesionales, ahorrar para el futuro y mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Salome is a member of the Bienestar communal bank. She is married, 42 years old and has 3 children. Salome has a store in her house in which she sells groceries, such as vegetables, meat, etc. with the help of her daughter. In addition, Salome has a car that her husband uses to transport passengers to various districts in the region. Salome needs a loan of 2100 Soles which will be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar and oil. Salome's dreams are that her children become professionals, saving money for the future and improving her business.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice, sugar and oil

loans.name: Lucia Virgenia

texts.es:
Lucia es socia del Banco Comunal Bienestar.
Lucia es casada, tiene 43 años y 4 hijos, Lucia tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, además tiene un bar en donde vende bebidas, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de sus hijas. En algunas oportunidades Lucia viaja a las ferias en donde compra carne y queso.
Lucia necesita un préstamo de 900 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cereales, queso, carne.
Lucia sueña con que sus hijos sean profesionales, tener una buena casa y comprar un carro.
texts.en:
Lucia is a member of the Bienestar communal bank. She is married, 43 years old and has 4 children. Lucia has a store in her house where she sells groceries. She also has a bar selling drink, which she does with the help of her daughters. Sometimes Lucia travels to various markets where she purchases meat and cheese to sell. Lucia needs a loan of 900 Soles which will be invested in the purchase of grains, cheese and meat. Lucia's dreams are that her children become professionals, having a good house and purchasing a car.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of grains, cheese and meat to sell

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.es:
Alfredo es socio del Banco Comunal Bienestar.
Alfredo es soltero y tiene 30 años, Alfredo es técnico dental de profesión, tiene un laboratorio dental en un local alquilado, sus productos los adquiere en la ciudad de Lima.
Alfredo necesita un préstamo de 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de materiales dentales,
Los sueños de Alfredo son ahorrar para el futuro y estudiar odontología.
texts.en:
Alfredo is a member of the Bienestar communal bank. He is single and 30 years old. Alfredo is a dental technician and has a dental laboratory in a rented location. He adquires his products in the city of Lima. Alfredo needs a loan of 1050 Soles which will be invested in the purchase of dental materials. Alfredo's dreams are to save money for the future and to study odontology.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of dental supplies

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Madame B. awa est une femme qui est mariée à un monsieur qui est un mécanicien automobile, elle a 03 enfants. Le revenu de son mari étant insuffisant pour couvrir toutes les charges du foyer, elle a commencé par exercer en 2005 le commerce de chaussures, elle y a associé aussi le commerce de produits génériques ce qui fait qu’elle réalise de bons chiffres d’affaire. Voulant agrandir son commerce pour attirer encore plus de clients, elle sollicite de WAGES un premiers crédits pour acheter des chaussures et des produits génériques. Elle s’approvisionne au marché local d’adawlato.
texts.en:
Mrs. Awa B. is married to a gentleman who is an automobile mechanic, and she has 3 children. The income of her husband is insufficient to cover all the household expenses, so she began selling shoes in 2005. She has also been selling generic products which allows her to have a good turnover. Wishing to expand her business so as to attract more customers, she is requesting her first loan from WAGES to buy shoes and generic products. She does her buying at the local market of Adawlato.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of shoes and generic products for re-sale

loans.name: Teofila

texts.es: Teofila es una madre de familia muy amorosa, tiene 43 años y vive en su propia casa junto a su único hijo Elvis de 9 años, y lo que más desea es darle una buena educación. La crianza de ganado es la actividad que desde muy niña realiza en la localidad de Jasana Capallino (Comunidad del distrito de Huancane), fue aprendiendo este negocio de sus padres, quienes siempre se preocuparon por darle una actividad con la cual defenderse en el futuro. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo a Teofila es pastar a sus animales, ya que disfruta mucho del aire libre, lleva 20 años en esta actividad y lo más difícil es llevar su ganado hasta las ferias dominicales de Huancane y Juliaca donde vende sus reses. Para el futuro espera incrementar la cantidad de ganado que tiene actualmente, para así mejor sus ingresos. Este es el primer préstamo de Teofila con MFP y está dispuesta a pagar todas sus cuotas puntualmente, en su banco comunal es una de las socias más cumplidas y puntuales. Con los 1000 soles solicitados comprará una ternerita lechera, la cual le costará aproximadamente 3500 soles, para completar ese monto pondrá parte de sus ahorros.
texts.en:
Teofila is a very caring mother who is 43 years old and lives in her own house along with her only son Elvis, who is 9 years old and for whom her main desire is to provide a good education. Raising livestock in the locality of Jasana Capallino (in the Huancane district), which she has done since she was little, is her economic activity. She learned this business from her parents, who always wanted to give her an activity with which to take care of herself in the future. What Teofila likes most about her job is shepherding the animals, since she enjoys the open air. In the 20 years she has done this work, the most difficult thing is taking her livestock to the Sunday markets in Huancane and Juliaca where she sells them. In the future, she hopes to increase the number of animals that she has to increase her income. This is her first loan with MFP and she is capable of making all of the payments punctually; in her communal bank she is one of the most punctual members. With the 1000 Soles requested she will buy a female calf, which will cost her 3500 Soles; to make up the rest she will use part of her savings.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a female calf

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr: Monsieur  K. kokou réside dans le quartier de hedrznawoè, il exerce le métier de réparateur d’appareil électronique, il y a associé le commerce de télévisions qu’il profite pour vendre à ses clients. Le commerce de télévision marche bien pour lui, il voudrait acheter plus de télévision et sollicite donc de WAGES un crédit qui lui permettrai d’acheter 10 télévisions et du matériel pour son travail. Il est marié et a 04 enfants.
texts.en:
Mr. Kokou K. resides in the Hedrznawoè neighborhood and repairs electrical appliances. He also sells TVs to his customers. The sales of TVs are going well for him. He would like to buy more TVs and so is requesting a loan from WAGES which will permit him to buy 10 televisions and some materials for his work. He is married and has 4 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of televisions for re-sale

loans.name: Yovana

texts.es: Yovana es una joven muy trabajadora, tiene 26 años y vive en la casa de sus padres con su única hija Elizabeth de 4 años, a quien quiere dar una mejor vida. La crianza de ganado es una actividad muy rentable, pues ella cuida muy bien a sus reses, los alimenta adecuadamente y los mantiene sanos, es por eso que su ganado es uno de los más solicitados en las ferias dominicales de Huancane y Juliaca. Lleva 6 años realizando esta actividad y lo que más le gusta es cuidar a sus animales, puesto que ella les tiene mucho cariño. En el futuro espera incrementar el número de reses que tiene, para mejorar sus ingresos, lo más difícil de su trabajo es llevar su ganado hasta las ferias, puesto que le es muy cansado, aun así sabe que tiene que trabajar muy duro para lograr alcanzar sus metas. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP y está dispuesta a pagar sus cuotas a tiempo, para no perjudicar a las demás socias de su banco comunal, donde es muy querida por la responsabilidad que demuestra. Con los 1000 soles solicitados planea comprar más forraje para su ganado y así alimentarlo mejor.
texts.en:
Yovana is a very hard-working young woman. She is 26 years old and lives in her parent's house with her only daughter Elizabeth, who is 4 years old and to whom she wants to give a better life. Raising cattle is a very profitable activity; she takes very good care of her animals, feeding them sufficietnely and keeping them healthy, which is why her cattle is some of the most requested in the Sunday markets of Huancane and Juliaca. She has been doing this for 6 years and what she most likes about the work is raising the animals, since she cares a lot about them. In the future, she hopes to increase the number of animals that she has in order to increase her income. The most difficult part of her job is taking the cattle to the markets, since it is very tiring although she knows that one has to work hard to realize his or her goals. This is her first loan with MFP and she is capable of making the payments on time, so as to not harm the rest of the member of her communal bank, where she is very admired for the responsibility that she demonstrates. With the 1000 Soles requested she plans to purchase more grazing food for her cattle to feed them better.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food for her animals

loans.name: Rosa Edith
